whiche

e common opinion, or for that,
as they alleage, it was not possible to hold it,
surrendred presently. The losse is esteemed to
be great, and suche as will turne
e Province of
Guelders
to very muche troble: especially if
those of
Sgravesweert
continewe their mutinie,
whiche is no otherwise likely. For their demaunde
doth amount to above

It is nowe in consultation heere, whether it be
expedient or not, to send againe
e Englishe
forces into those quarters. For it is not thought
that
e Enemie doth lie so strong but that
he may be easely repulsed. Howbeit there is
nothing yet resolved. There is
also an other newe mutinie growen in the
castell of
Wijcke,
a place of great importance,
about 2 leagues from
Utrecht,
Uppon
e river:
where
e garrison refuseth to yeld obedience to
the states, desireth to be discharged of their
othe, and requireth to receave their full count
and reckning. The state is muche trobled about
it, and can not resolve, whether it be best to
give them present contentment, w

nes, to be subject to persons of no more vertue
and worthe. But before
e Contrey be redu-
ced to some daungerous extremitie, this gene-
